answers.answer: The "Oh no, not again" was my comment, not part of the article.  I meant for that to go at the top of the page before the link, but somehow I managed to put it right in the middle.Oops.

"Center may have been exposed to HIV, hepatitis B or hepatitis C because of accidental reuse of insulin pens."How in the world can they accident ally reuse insulin pens?...OMG this is just horrible...
Reusing syringes or anything else used for injections is DANGEROUS!  Shouldn't we be able to expect medical professionals to know that?This stuff makes me so mad.

Most facilities use a seperate pen per patent, but some DO use the same pen, and change the needles, that's not really that unheard of.  This is definitely not an HIV risk, and would be a VERRRRY low risk for anything else.  Minute.With the nature of how the pen works, it's not like anything gets drawn INTO the pen that could cause a risk that way.  Obviously when they say "accidental reuse", it was their policy to not share pens amongst patients, therefore, they are definitely on the hook that way, for not following their own policies.

While the risk may be low I don't think it is appropriate to be switching needles on the same syringe/pen that is used with multiple patients. It just looks bad and apparently this had been going on for over 2 years. That "accidental reuse" doesn't look like accidental to me. It looks like it was their standard procedure.Mike

While the risk may be low I don't think it is appropriate to be switching needles on the same syringe/pen that is used with multiple patients.I don't disagree.  I think it's poor practice, I just know that some places DO do that.  Problem of course (one of them anyway), is that proper protocol isn't followed, like the pen being thoroughly cleaned with alcohol in between uses.Also, yea, "accidental" is a silly way to put it.  It was either their lacking procedural protocol, or it was laziness.

Diabetes is the one of the most mismanaged chronic diseases in this country and until very recently diabetes care in most hospitals had been abysmal. And I'm not limiting my statement to just small town hospitals. Large scale university affiliated teaching hospitals haven't done very well with diabetes either. Finally it seems as though this very serious problem is getting the type of attention that it deserves - people are waking up. But really, little would surprise me when it comes to diabetic care or the lack thereof.

question: There is a small risk that diabetic patients at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Buffalo, NY might have been exposed to HIF, hepatitis B or hepatitis C.BUFFALO, N.Y. — The Veterans Administration has told western New York members of Congress that more than 700 patients at the Buffalo VA Medical Center may have been exposed to HIV, hepatitis B or hepatitis C because of accidental reuse of insulin pens.Oh no, not again!http://news.msn.com/us/possible-hiv-exposure-at-buffalo-va-hospitalAuthorities tell The Buffalo News that there's a "very small risk" for the diabetic patients who may have been exposed to the reused insulin pens between October 2010 and November 2012.The VA memo obtained by the News says the problem was revealed by a routine pharmacy inspection.A hospital spokeswoman says the needles were always changed, but an insulin pen may have been used on more than one patient.The VA is offering free blood tests to rule out any infections.
title: Possible HIV exposure at Buffalo VA hospital
